slide.text: ##What is the distance formula? The formula gives the distance between two points $(\greenD{x_1}, \goldD{y_1})$ and $(\greenD{x_2}, \goldD{y_2})$ on the coordinate plane: $\sqrt{(\greenD{x_2 - x_1})^2 + (\goldD{y_2 - y_1})^2}$ It is derived from the Pythagorean theorem. [[☃ image 1]] *Want to learn more about the distance formula? Check out [this video](v/distance-formula).* ## What problems can I solve with the distance formula? Given two points on the plane, you can find their distance. For example, let's find the distance between $(\greenD1, \goldD2)$ and $(\greenD9, \goldD8)$: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\sqrt{(\greenD{x_2 - x_1})^2 + (\goldD{y_2 - y_1})^2} \\\\ &=\sqrt{(\greenD{9 -1})^2 + (\goldD{8 - 2})^2}\quad\small\gray{\text{Plug in coordinates}} \\\\ &=\sqrt{8^2+6^2} \\\\ &=\sqrt{100} \\\\ &=10 \end{align}$ Notice: we were careful to put the $x$-coordinates together and the $y$-coordinates together and not mix them up. ## Check your understanding [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] *Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/distance_formula).*

##What is the midpoint formula? The formula gives the midpoint of the points $(\greenD{x_1}, \goldD{y_1})$ and $(\greenD{x_2}, \goldD{y_2})$ in the coordinate plane: $\left(\greenD{\dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2}}, \goldD{\dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2}}\right)$ [[☃ image 1]] *Want to learn more about the midpoint formula? Check out [this video](v/midpoint-formula).* ## What problems can I solve with the midpoint formula? Given two points on the plane, you can find their midpoint. For example, let's find the midpoint of $(\greenD5, \goldD3)$ and $(\greenD1, \goldD7)$: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\left(\greenD{\dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2}}, \goldD{\dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2}}\right) \\\\ &=\left(\greenD{\dfrac{5+1}{2}}, \goldD{\dfrac{3+7}{2}}\right)\quad\small\gray{\text{Plug in coordinates}} \\\\ &=(\greenD3, \goldD5) \end{align}$ Notice: we were careful to put the $x$-coordinates together and the $y$-coordinates together and not mix them up. ## Check your understanding [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] *Want to try more problems like this? Check out [this exercise](/e/midpoint_formula).*

The $\blueD{\text{midpoint}}$ of the points $(\greenD{x_1}, \goldD{y_1})$ and $(\greenD{x_2}, \goldD{y_2})$ is given by the following formula: $\left(\greenD{\dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2}}, \goldD{\dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2}}\right)$ In this article, we're going to derive this formula! ##Deriving the midpoint formula Let's start by plotting the points $(\greenD{x_1}, \goldD{y_1})$ and $(\greenD{x_2}, \goldD{y_2})$. [[☃ image 1]] The $\blueD{\text{midpoint}}$ is the point halfway between each of the points: [[☃ image 2]] An expression for the $x$-coordinate of the $\blueD{\text{midpoint}}$ is $\greenD{\dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2}}$: [[☃ explanation 1]] [[☃ image 3]] Similarly, an expression for the $y$-coordinate of the $\blueD{\text{midpoint}}$ is $\goldD{\goldD{\dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2}}}$: [[☃ image 4]] That's it! We derived the following formula for the $\blueD{\text{midpoint}}$! $\left(\greenD{\dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2}}, \goldD{\dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2}}\right)$ Interestingly, a lot of people don't memorize this exact formula. Instead, they remember that to find the midpoint, you take the average of the $x$-coordinates and the average of the $y$-coordinates. ##Practice problem [[☃ graded-group 1]] [[☃ explanation 2]]

Let’s refresh some concepts that will come in handy as you start the analytic geometry unit of the high school geometry course. You’ll see a summary of each concept, along with a sample item, links for more practice, and some info about why you will need the concept for the unit ahead. There are a lot of sections in this article because analytic geometry pulls together a lot of ideas! This article only includes concepts from earlier courses. There are also concepts within this high school geometry course that are important to understanding analytic geometry. If you have not yet mastered the [Pythagorean theorem lesson](/math/geometry/hs-geo-trig#hs-geo-pyth-theorem), it may be helpful for you to review that before going farther into the unit ahead. ##Points on a coordinate plane ###What is this, and why do we need it? We use a coordinate plane to show relative position in 2D space. We describe every point on the plane with an ordered pair in the form $(x, y)$, where $x$ represents the horizontal position, and $y$ represents the vertical position. Points to the left of the [[☃ definition 2]] have negative $x$-coordinates, and points to the right have positive $x$-coordinates. Likewise, points below the origin have negative $y$-coordinates, and points above the origin have positive $y$-coordinates. ###Practice [[☃ graded-group 1]] For more practice, go to [Points on the coordinate plane](/e/identifying_points_1). ###Where will we use this? We will use points on a coordinate plane in almost every exercise in the analytic geometry unit! Here are a few of the exercises where reviewing the coordinate plane might be helpful: - [Distance between two points](/e/distance_formula) - [Divide line segments](/e/dividing-line-segments) - [Area & perimeter on the coordinate plane](/e/find-area-and-perimeter-on-the-coordinate-plane) ##Adding, subtracting, and squaring negative numbers ###What is this, and why do we need it? Negative numbers let us include direction information in a number. For example, a positive vertical change means we've gone up, but a negative vertical change means we've gone down. We'll be looking for distances and slopes between points on the coordinate plane. Points with negative coordinates are to the left of or below the [[☃ definition 1]]. ###Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 2]] For more practice, go to [Adding negative numbers](/e/adding_negative_numbers), [Subtracting negative numbers](/e/adding_and_subtracting_negative_numbers), or [Exponents with integer bases](/e/exponents_1.5). ###Where will we use this? Here are a few of the exercises where reviewing negative numbers might be helpful: - [Midpoint formula](/e/midpoint_formula) - [Distance between two points](/e/distance_formula) - [Parallel & perpendicular lines from graph](/e/classifying-lines-as-parallel--perpendicular--or-neither) ##Distance and displacement between points ###What is this, and why do we need it? Distance is how far apart two points are and is always non-negative. Displacement is the amount of change to go from one point to the other, including both distance and the direction of the change. We often break distance and displacement into their horizontal and vertical parts. When we are only working with one direction of change (only horizontal or only vertical), then the distance is the absolute value of the displacement. We use displacement to calculate slope, and we use the horizontal and vertical distances between points to find their total distance (with a little help from the Pythagorean theorem). ###Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] For more practice, go to [Distance between points: vertical and horizontal](/e/relative-position-on-the-coordinate-plane). ###Where will we use this? Here are a few of the exercises where reviewing distances and displacements might be helpful. - [Distance between two points](/e/distance_formula) - [Area & perimeter on the coordinate plane](/e/find-area-and-perimeter-on-the-coordinate-plane) - [Points inside/outside/on a circle](/e/geometry-problems-on-the-coordinate-plane) ##Simplifying square root expressions ###What is this, and why do we need it? For geometry, the square root function takes the area of a square as the input and give the length of a side of the square as an output. We'll use square root expressions when we use the Pythagorean theorem to find a distance. We'll use those distances to find area and perimeter of figures on the coordinate plane and to determine whether a point is part of a circle. ###Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] For more practice, go to [Simplify square roots](/e/simplifying_radicals) and [Simplify square root expressions](/e/adding_and_subtracting_radicals). ###Where will we use this? Here are a couple of the exercises where reviewing square root expressions might be helpful. - [Points inside/outside/on a circle](/e/geometry-problems-on-the-coordinate-plane=post) - [Area & perimeter on the coordinate plane](/e/find-area-and-perimeter-on-the-coordinate-plane) ##Scaling proportional relationships ###What is this, and why do we need it? Proportional relationships are two quantities where the ratio between the two quantities always stays the same. Slope is a kind of proportional relationship that relates the vertical displacement (or change) to the horizontal displacement. We can scale the displacements between two points to find a third point between them that divides a line segment into lengths with a given ratio. ###Practice [[☃ graded-group 1]] For more practice, go to [Create double number lines](/e/create-double-number-lines). ###Where will we use this? Here is an exercise where reviewing scaling proportional relationships might be helpful: - [Divide line segments](/e/dividing-line-segments) ##Slope ###What is this, and why do we need it? Slope is one way of measuring how steep a line is. We measure slope as $\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}$, which is the ratio of the vertical displacement to the horizontal displacement. We can use the slope of a pair of lines to prove that they are parallel (or that they're not!). Then we can tell whether we can apply all of those relationships among the angles of figures with parallel lines. If use the slope to prove that two sides of a triangle are perpendicular, we can use trigonometric ratios to relate their angle measures and side lengths. ###Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] For more practice, go to [Slope from two points](/e/slope-from-two-points), [Slope-intercept intro](/e/slope-from-an-equation-in-slope-intercept-form), and [Slope from equation](/e/slope-from-an-equation-in-standard-form). ###Where will we use this? Here are a few of the exercises where reviewing slope might be helpful. - [Parallel & perpendicular lines from graph](/e/classifying-lines-as-parallel--perpendicular--or-neither) - [Parallel & perpendicular lines from equation](/e/line_relationships) - [Write equations of parallel & perpendicular lines](/e/writing-equations-for-parallel-or-perpendicular-lines)

The $\blueD{\text{distance}}$ between the points $(\greenD{x_1}, \goldD{y_1})$ and $(\greenD{x_2}, \goldD{y_2})$ is given by the following formula: >$\sqrt{(\greenD{x_2 - x_1})^2 + \goldD{(y_2 - y_1})^2}$ In this article, we're going to derive this formula! ##Deriving the distance formula Let's start by plotting the points $(\greenD{x_1}, \goldD{y_1})$ and $(\greenD{x_2}, \goldD{y_2})$. [[☃ image 1]] The length of the segment between the two points is the $\blueD{\text{distance}}$ between them: [[☃ image 2]] We want to find the $\blueD{\text{distance}}$. If we draw a right triangle, we'll be able to use the Pythagorean theorem! [[☃ image 3]] An expression for the length of the base is $\greenD{x_2 - x_1}$: [[☃ explanation 1]] [[☃ image 4]] Similarly, an expression for the length of the height is $\goldD{y_2 -y_1}$: [[☃ image 5]] Now we can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation: >$\blueD{?}^2 \, = (\greenD{x_2 - x_1})^2 + \goldD{(y_2 - y_1})^2$ We can solve for $\blueD ?$ by taking the square root of each side: >$\blueD ? = \sqrt{(\greenD{x_2 - x_1})^2 + \goldD{(y_2 - y_1})^2}$ That's it! We derived the distance formula! Interestingly, a lot of people don't actually memorize this formula. Instead, they set up a right triangle, and use the Pythagorean theorem whenever they want to find the distance between two points.

slide.text: ## How do we divide a line segment into two segments with a certain ratio of lengths? There a few ways to solve this type of problem. One way to is to apply the given ratio to both the horizontal and vertical displacements between the points. For example, if point $A$ is at $(0,0)$, point $C$ is at $(8,4)$, and we want to find point $B$ such that $AB$ is $\dfrac34$ of $AC$, we can use a strategy like this: [[☃ image 1]] - The horizontal displacement is $8$ units, and $\dfrac34$ of $8$ is $6$. - The vertical displacement is $4$ units, and $\dfrac34$ of $4$ is $3$. ## How do we divide a line segment into two segments with a certain ratio of lengths given the coordinates of the endpoints? Let's start by defining our variables. We'll call the coordinates of the endpoints $A$ and $B$. We'll also call the ratio of the lengths $r$. Now, let's think about what we're trying to do. We want to find a point $P$ on the line segment that divides it into two segments, $AP$ and $PB$, with lengths that have a ratio of $r$. We can use a formula to find the coordinates of $P$: $\left[P = \dfrac{rB + A}{r+1}\right] $ This formula works in any dimension, so we can use it for both 2D and 3D line segments. To recap, we need to know the coordinates of the two endpoints, $A$ and $B$, and the ratio of the lengths, $r$. We plug those values into the formula, and we'll get the coordinates for $P$. ## What's the difference between parallel and perpendicular lines? Parallel lines are two lines that will never intersect. They have the same slope, or steepness. Perpendicular lines, on the other hand, intersect at a $90$ degree angle. Their slopes are opposite reciprocals of each other. For example, if one line has the slope $\dfrac{2}{3}$, the perpendicular line will have the slope $-\dfrac{3}{2}$. ## How do we find the equation of a parallel or perpendicular line? To find the equation of a parallel line, we'll use the same slope as the original line, but a different $y$-intercept. If we know a point $\left(x_1,y_1\right)$ through which the parallel line passes, we can substitute the coordinates into the point-slope formula, where $m$ represents the slope of the line. $y-y_1=m(x-x_1)$ To find the equation of a perpendicular line, we'll use the opposite reciprocal slope, and then use the point-slope formula to find the $y$-intercept. ## Where are these topics used in the real world? Cartographers (map-makers) often use coordinate geometry to draw accurate maps. Architects and engineers use these concepts when designing buildings and bridges. Computer graphics designers use coordinate geometry to create realistic 3D images.
